title: Index introspection API missing important information
body:
```
In [5]: ds.list_indices()
Out[5]:
[{'name': 'vector_idx',
  'type': 'Vector',
  'uuid': '0b253ef1-08cd-4452-b2c2-72d5d31e98b6',
  'fields': ['vector'],
  'version': 102}]
```

it would be much more useful to also return index specific information, e.g.:

type: "IVF_PQ"
num_partitions: 256
num_sub_vectors: 32
num_dimensions: 1536
distance_metric: "l2"

This can be returned in list_indices. But if it's expensive, could be a separate API that retrieves by the index uuid.

title: Clean up `copy` `rename` logic
body: according to https://github.com/apache/arrow-rs/issues/4758, `copy` is suppose to be atomic. However, currently `copy` is not atomic and we use `copy` to tmp file and `rename` to dest as a workaround. Clean up these workarounds once https://github.com/apache/arrow-rs/issues/4758 land

title: add logic to clean up stray staged manifests
body: In #1190 we added `ExternalManifestStore`, where we first write a manifest with a random path. This manifest with a random path could become orphaned and needs to be cleaned up.

title: Collect fragment-level statistics on commit
[Python][Rust] Design a Image extension type
body:
# Problem Statement

To improve data lake for multi-model data, we could provide a Image type as arrow extension type for users to easily manipulate data.

Requirements:

* Be able to store image in a form that easy to inspect, store, integration with the existing image / computer vision tooling
* Be able to load into pytorch and tensorflow as tensors transparently.
* Strong typed that we can apply special kernel during projection, and filtering.

Previous related work:

We have done similar work in the framework of Spark Extension type and Parquet , and PyTorch

* https://github.com/eto-ai/rikai/blob/main/python/rikai/types/vision.py
* Pytorch: https://github.com/eto-ai/rikai/blob/main/python/rikai/pytorch/transforms.py

title: move manifest path logic into commit handler
body:
This PR moves two hard coded functions `manifest_path` and `latest_manifest_path` into `CommitHandler` trait.

`CommitHandler` is now where we define logic for "here is a uri to a dataset, I want to get a version/put a version"

## Why this PR?
In #1190 a major problem I ran into is the tight coupling of logic for determining where a manifest is. We used to use `manifest_path` and `latest_manifest_path` in many places of the code base. However, hardcoded function makes customizing manifest commit logic tricky as we frequently would need to change all callsites. With this PR, we can customize manifest path resolving logic with IoC, where we can change the behavior by "injecting" a new `CommitHandler` implementation.

title: feat: update the commit function to work with transactions
body:
Previously the commit function did not use the new transactions feature.  This meant that a commit running concurrently with another operation could lead to bad behavior.  The commit operation was also limited mostly to overwrites.

Now commits can apply any kind of transaction operation.

part of #1183 <-- detailed design is here too

This PR implements
* `trait ExternalManifestStore` which abstracts an KV-like store with `put_if_not_exists` capability
* `ExternalManifestCommitHandler` which takes a trait object of `ExternalManifestStore` and handles concurrent write to lance dataset using this `dyn ExternalManifestStore`

title: Remove request dependency as it's only used for its re-export of http
body: depend on http for it's header types instead of request's re-export of the module

title: Rust reqwest dependency with all features makes cross compiling difficult
body:
We've been trying to rely on rustls to avoid system openssl issues, the object_store crate actually enables this by turning off reqwest default_features:

https://github.com/apache/arrow-rs/blob/735f48d1f2ebd7e6edb4df167f4f3e91d33f84a4/object_store/Cargo.toml#L53

I'm not sure if there's conditional compilation stuff that we can do, or if y'all wanna just rely on rustls because you already are transitively through object_store, but easier cross compilation would be cool.

FWIW I can get around this by declaring a dependency on openssl and using its "vendor" feature, but, it would be nice to not have to compile openssl

title: use commit handler to find the latest version of a dataset
body:
part of #1183

This PR adds `get_latest_version` to `CommitHandler` and use the commit handler to resolve latest version in `Dataset::open`

title: [python] Validate schema metadata
body:
arrow ffi requires schema metadata k/v to be valid utf8. And it segfaults if it encounters an invalid byte value. To store binary data (like pickled functions), this will be a problem. Instead we will store base64 encoded pickle bytes. But we still add a safety check here to make sure all schema metadata values are valid utf8

Closes #1178

title: Make Rust benchmark builds faster
body:
Benchmarks are very slow to build, mostly because (1) we have a very large library and (2) we have many benchmarks binaries, which each need to independently link to our very large binary. Unless I set `--jobs 1`, I run out of memory trying to build them.

For the microbenchmarks, most of our benchmarks are our optimized distance functions and linear algebra functions. If we put them in a separate sub-crate (`lance-compute`?), then it should be must faster to link the microbenchmarks. We might even be able to consolidate the binaries for an additional benefit.

For macro benchmarks, we should probably move them over to the Python benchmarks in the top-level `benchmarks` directory. Then we just have to link one Python library and we can re-use it for as many benchmarks as we want.

## TODO

* [x] #1218
* [ ] Separate algorithms into smaller library and benchmark separately.

title: RFC: S3 concurrent writer via dynamoDB
body:
## Context
S3 does not support transactional-operations like `*_if_not_exist`.
We would like to support transactional-operations on S3 for concurrent writers.

## Requirements
* Implement a native locking mechanism in Lance to support `*_if_not_exist` on s3.
* This new mechanism should be usable in all language lance binds to.
* Ensure we still have snapshot isolation. (unsuccessful and en route commit should not be visable)
* (Nice to have) Pave the road for redis/sql based commit mechanisms.

## Why DynamoDB?
Out of the three major Cloud providers, AWS(S3), GCP(GCS), and Azure(Blob Storage), S3 is only one that does not provide transactional semantics in its APIs. This means, it is okay to use an AWS native solution as we do not need to port this locking mechanism to other cloud providers.

(minio, http, et al. will probably use redis/sql commit mechanism)

## Interface
Since this is a S3-only feature, it doesn't make a lot of sense to add more params to `ObjectStoreParams` nor `[Read|Write]Params`.

The proposed solution is to pass in dynamo params as part of the s3 URI with the following syntax
```
s3+ddb://<bucket>/<path>?ddbTableName=<ddb_table_name>
```

## Problems with dynamodb-lock-rs
The library does not support unexpirable locks. This means, the library can only support synchronous* fail-stop model. (*: the lock lease duration effectively converts async consensus into a sync consensus with time as epoch boundaries).

This can cause data corruption under pause or network partition failure model. (The lock can expire while manifest commit is still going on)

## Problem with unexpirable locks
They can crash-deadlock and are only recoverable by manual intervention

## Crux of the problem
Having two sources of truth makes consensus with strong consistency requirement not possible. (S3 is the source of truth for manifest version, while Dynamo is the source of truth of which writer's manifest is valid)

## Proposed solution

![external_store_commit](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/assets/12615154/9e2eeb6c-c7c3-4af5-9b97-a0fff7407902)


When committing to S3, we can use the following procedure

For procedure `commit(manifest: Manifest)` do

1. Write the manifest we want to commit to S3 with a temporary name e.g. `dataset.lance/_versions/staging/152a8c85-e4e7-4a1f-96d1-1cef1c6dbd9d.manifest`
2. Try to commit this version to dynamodb with `attribute_not_exists(PK) AND attribute_not_exists(SK)` condition. Where the committed data would look like
```
{
  pk: {table_uri}, <-- String
  sk: {version}, <-- int
  commiter: <hostname>, <-- String
  uri: <temporary_uri> <-- String
}
```
3. If dynamodb commit fails, return err
4. Writer proceed to call `copy` and copy the manifest from temporary path to `dataset.lance/_version/{version}.manifest`
5. Update DynamoDB with `dataset.lance/_version/{version}.manifest`

### What if step 4 fails?
To address this problem,  We should always load manifest from dynamodb.
When loading manifest we can use the following procedure:

For procedure `checkout_latest(uri: &str)` do

1. The loader reach out to dynamodb first and find the latest version V of the dataset.
2. Ensure step 4, 5 on commit loop is done, if not, retry 4, 5

This checkout procedure can guarantee that
1. When DynamoDB and S3 go out of sync, S3 is at most behind by one version
2. All operations are blocked until the two stores are in sync again

### Caveats
This solution changes the source of truth for manifests from s3 to dynamodb. This means
* Reader and writer must both use dynamodb to ensure consistency
* To off-board dynamodb, user would have to make sure the s3 and dynamodb are in sync before they can safely off-board.

## Execution Plan
- [x] add `checkout` method to `CommitHandler`
- [x] implement `ExternalManifestCommitHandler`
- [x] implement `DynamoDBS3CommitHandler`
- [x] implement parsing in `io::ObjectStore` to recognize `s3+ddb://` scheme
- [ ] #1206

title: [Bug] Lance dataset writes crashes with non-string bytes in the schema metadata

```python

def test_schema_with_bytes_metadata(tmp_path: Path):
    schema = pa.schema(
        [pa.field("a", pa.float64())], metadata={"key": pickle.dumps("value")}
    )
    data = pa.table({"a": [1.0, 2.0]}).to_batches()

    assert dataset.schema == schema
```

title: [bug] sigsegv when saving large dataframe
body:
User reported on Discord:

```
Hey folks, I'm experimenting with Lance and having a small issue. I have a very large pd DataFrame that it fails to save on my 32GB M1 Pro. I get a SIGSEGV.
For scale, around 16M rows. turns out to be 2.2GB .parquet file with gzip. Works with smaller shards. 
(I'm aware that Lance supports appending but I wanted to test it purely as a drop-in replacement)
```

schema:

```
OUTPUT_DTYPES: dict = {
    'paper_id': 'uint32',
    'section': 'string',
    'single_text': 'string',
    'multi_text': 'string',
    'single_challenge_score': 'float32',
    'single_direction_score': 'float32',
    'multi_challenge_score': 'float32',
    'multi_direction_score': 'float32'
}

# And this is the code I use to generate it
batch_df: pd.DataFrame = pd.DataFrame({k: pd.Series(dtype=t) for k, t in OUTPUT_DTYPES.items()})
# This df ends up having around 16M rows

```

```
After I'm done concatenating from all shards, this is the original way I saved the file:
# This line crashes with the pyarrow engine!
batch_df.to_parquet(batch_output_path, engine="fastparquet", compression="gzip", index=False)

And when using lance I swap it with
lance.write_dataset(batch_df, batch_output_path)
 
I've created a separate branch to append each shard normally (instead of one massive dataset) and it works perfectly fine. It's the large df that makes it crash
```

title: [bench] Fix up rust benchmarks
body:
- Move `generate_random_array` and `generate_random_array_with_seed` to datagen.rs
- Limit utils::testing to cfg[test] but include utils::datagen without the `#cfg[test]` predicate
- Add a CI step to build the benchmark code (without running them).
- Changed references from utils::testing::generate_random_array* to utils::datagen::generate_random_array* in a bunch of places.

title: Report "total bytes freed" in cleanup stats
body: The cleanup task currently reports the number of files that were removed.  We should also report how many bytes of disk space were freed as that is likely to be a more useful statistic for users.

title: Inject clock instead of using process-wide clock
body:
Currently, if we need to get the current time, we use something like `Utc::now` or `SystemTime::now`.  These use process-wide clocks, which is fine, but which are difficult to mock out for testing (see tests in the `cleanup.rs`).  What we end up doing to test this is mocking out the process-wide clock but this means these tests cannot run in parallel (since they would interfere with each other's mocking).

Instead, we could make a dataset's clock configurable.  This would allow us to change it during testing without impacting other running tests.

title: feat: add support for field metdata
feat: add a background executor for Python
body:
Closes #736.

This PR consolidates all the tokio runtimes being created into a single runtime running in a background thread. This prevents the issues we've seen with calling `block_on` inside an async runtime if we, for example, pass a RBR that calls into tokio into `write_dataset()`.

There are a couple implications for having these tasks execute in a background thread:

1. There's a higher likelihood a GIL deadlocks, since our tasks might be calling into Python hooks that need to acquire the GIL. Thus I've started adding some `Python::allow_threads()` calls where necessary.
2. The future we run now need to be `Send + 'static` so they can be moved to another thread.

title: Improve dataset merge behavior when overlapping columns exist
body:
Currently if there are any overlapping columns other than the join column, then an error is raised: `OSError: Invalid user input: Column xxx exists in both sides of the dataset`
This requires users to manually select the right columns first, which is inconvenient.
Instead, let's consider adding a parameter that supports ignoring overlapping columns instead of always raising an exception.

title: implement flat vector index benchmark
body:
This PR implements a flat index search benchmark. The benchmark script generates random data and writes to a dataset. Then, we search a few times using flat index, i.e. brute force.

The script generates a `benchmark.html` and `benchmark.csv` file. The html file is an interactive plot of the latency data, the csv file is the raw data.

title: [Python, Benchmarks] How could we ship binary wheel with different CPU targets
body:
# Problem Statement

The default target-cpu of our pypi release is `--target-cpu=haswell` to enable AVX2 and FMA code path. However, @chebbyChefNEQ has found that running `--target-cpu=native` on a Zen 4 (7950X?) platform leads to more than 10X speed up over vector indexing performance, and would expect non-trivial speed up in query path as well.

# Desired Behavior 

If this speed gap can not be bridged by feature flag (`#[cfg=...]`) in rust, we need to think about how we release binaries that can take advantage of the CPU users have, and dont leave performance on the table.

title: fix: Copying schema metadata in the Scanner
body:
- The root cause of the issue is that the scanner re-creates the `RecordBatch` schema in a couple of different places without copying the original metadata
- When `concat_batches` sees a different schema between `RecordBatches` it throws an exception
- Overall this process is a little brittle - there are a lot of different places creating schemas, and not all of them need the metadata
- I opted to change the existing test cases instead of creating new ones so they could cover a variety of use cases

Close #1152

title: [Rust] Compute dot distance as negative dot product
body: To make the sorting of dot distance mathematically correct. The bigger the dot product is, the closer two vectors are.

title: docs: document commit API as basis for distributed writes
body:
This is a first pass at providing "distributed" examples. I ran out of time to do anything more elaborate. For now, we demonstrate the distributed APIs just in a REPL, which helps convey the concepts. Later, we can add notebooks showing how these integrate into a framework like PySpark or something else.

This PR makes `LanceDataset.commit()` a public API. We already have users using it and we've just made the API improved, so I think this is something we'll want to do. It is labelled as an advanced API in various place though.

Closes #1179

title: fix docs build
Expose AWS creds and region configurability to python
body: We added aws creds injection in #1059 and region injection in #1153. Currently these APIs are not exposed to python binding, where user still have to rely on the default cred chain to get creds. This is okay most of the time, but it would be nice to be able to use custom creds for situations like assume role.

title: feat: pass commit handler on dataset load
expose aws region configurability
body: previously we could only set aws region via env var and IMDS, this PR opens up configuration during construction

title: Indexing fails when schema contains metadata written from schema specified in `write_dataset`
body:
repro
```python
import pyarrow as pa
import lance

t = pa.Table.from_pylist(
    [{"test": [0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4]}],
    schema=pa.schema([pa.field("test", pa.list_(pa.float32(), 4))]),
)
ds = lance.write_dataset(
    t.to_batches(), # force the schema below to be picked up
    "test.lance",
    schema=t.schema.with_metadata({"lance": "test"}),
    mode="overwrite",
)
ds.create_index(
    "test",
    "IVF_PQ",
    num_partitions=1,
    num_sub_vectors=1
)
```
output
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rmeng/workspace/lance/benchmarks/wiki/test.py", line 14, in <module>
    ds.create_index(
  File "/home/rmeng/workspace/lance/python/python/lance/dataset.py", line 659, in create_index
    self._ds.create_index(column, index_type, name, metric, kwargs)
OSError: LanceError(Arrow): Invalid argument error: batches[0] schema is different with argument schema.
            batches[0] schema: Schema { fields: [Field { name: "test", data_type: FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: Float32, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 4), nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }], metadata: {} },
            argument schema: Schema { fields: [Field { name: "test", data_type: FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: Float32, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 4), nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }], metadata: {"lance": "test"} }
```

title: Better handle schema mismatch when writing dataset
body:
```python
import pyarrow as pa
import lance

t = pa.Table.from_pylist([{"test": [1, 2, 3]}])
ds = lance.write_dataset(
    t,
    "test.lance",
    schema=pa.schema([pa.field("test", pa.list_(pa.float32(), 32))]),
    mode="overwrite",
)
print(f"===> schema with pa.Table: \n{t.schema}, lance: \n{ds.schema}")

batch = pa.RecordBatch.from_pylist([{"test": [1, 2, 3]}])
ds = lance.write_dataset(
    pa.RecordBatch.from_pylist([{"test": [1, 2, 3]}]),
    "test.lance",
    schema=pa.schema([pa.field("test", pa.list_(pa.float32(), 32))]),
    mode="overwrite",
)
print(f"===> schema with pa.RecordBatch: \n{batch.schema}, lance: \n{ds.schema}")

lance.write_dataset(
    [pa.RecordBatch.from_pylist([{"test": [1, 2, 3]}])],
    "test.lance",
    schema=pa.schema([pa.field("test", pa.list_(pa.float32(), 32))]),
    mode="overwrite",
)
```
the above script yields output:
```
===> schema with pa.Table:
test: list<item: int64>
  child 0, item: int64, lance:
test: list<item: int64>
  child 0, item: int64
===> schema with pa.RecordBatch:
test: list<item: int64>
  child 0, item: int64, lance:
test: list<item: int64>
  child 0, item: int64
munmap_chunk(): invalid pointer
[1]    472488 IOT instruction (core dumped)  python test.py
```

In the first two cases, maybe we should print a warning about setting `schema=` when the data source is `pa.Table | pa.RecordBatch`, where the specified schema is ignored.

In the third case, we crash on `abort` because the list of record batch and schema mismatches. (ideally user would call with RBR, but sometime just passing a list of RecordBatches is convenient.0

title: feat: add count_rows to scanner
body:
Adds a `count_rows` method to the scanner which will take any existing scanner filter into account.

Closes #841

title: Sort Dot Product correctly
body:
# Problem Statement

When we use dot product as distance metric, the bigger the value is, the more similar two vectors are, so we should either use `argmax(dot_product(v1, v2))` or `argmin(neg(dot_product(v1, v2))` for index sorting.

title: Write chunked batch at the Fragment level
body:
To facilitate the distributed writers, we should have the fine-granularity write control at the Fragment level

Right now, the chunked stream of RecordBatch is done at the global level 

https://github.com/lancedb/lancedb/blob/f35f8e451fb6b8f83ca4bad68aefb22c1341eece/node/src/arrow.ts#L36, which only works if we have one single writer.

title: Add restore command
body:
Users can checkout previous versions, but we'd like them to also be able to restore previous versions as the current version so they can check it out.

When checking out old versions, we should make it obvious in the repr it is an old version and not meant to be a reference to the new version.

We should also expose a restore method that restores the table to that version, making it the latest version.

In addition, when the write method (`append()`, `delete()`, etc.) are called on the historical version, we should only write if a `force=True` parameter is given. When writes are done, first a restore transaction is committed, and then it continues with the expected operation.

title: AWS Credentials
body:
Greetings, 
Locally I can connect Lance to s3 storage using my ENV AWS keys but on Kubernetes AWS/EKS im running into an unexpected issue. The error i get is this one
```
panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: CredentialsNotLoaded(CredentialsNotLoaded { source: "no providers in chain provided credentials" })', /home/runner/work/lance/lance/rust/src/io/object_store.rs:118:83
```
The reason why this is unexpected for me is that on EKS/K8s I typically run many services that use the AWS Creds/Service Account on the nodes such that I typically do not need to specify additional keys when running on pods in those nodes - My pods load a default region via env too.

Looking through the lance code im not 100% sure if there is definitely a need for me to do something extra here to specify credentials for AWS and if so, what are my options for passing creds. Is there anything i should load into the env? Do i need to configure something that I have not thought of in the connect constructor?? 

Any pointers appreciated.

Cheers

title: feat: switch session caches to use moka cache instead of LruCache
body:
Closes #1130 

Moka cache should be more performant when accessed from multiple threads concurrently.

title: Migrate lance's session cache to moka
body:
The `lance::session::FileMetadataCache` is currently using `LruCache`.  We should instead use [moka](https://docs.rs/moka/0.11.2/moka/)

From `@wjones127` 
> Motivation is performance, although this isn't an acute pain point yet. Within a single query we may access that cache from multiple threads. Right now it controls access with a Mutex, but Moka's cache should handle concurrency better

title: Use DF's planner directly for expression (filter) parsing
body:
Currently, lance implements its own parser/planner logic in `planner.rs` in order to convert filters from SQL to datafusion expressions.  This means we have to make extensions to lance's planner/parser to expose new capabilities as DF releases them (e.g. https://github.com/lancedb/lance/issues/1115 ).  It would be easier to reuse DF's planner/parser directly.  I've started an experiment to do this here: https://github.com/lancedb/lance/compare/main...westonpace:lance:experiment/use-df-planner?expand=1

There are a few prerequisite tasks before we can complete this.

- [ ] https://github.com/lancedb/lance/issues/849 - Lance's planner is designed to enable `pyarrow.compute.Expression -> string -> DF` expression.  So it makes some choices (like a default timestamp resolution of microseconds) that are different than datafusion's planner.  If we can instead go `pyarrow.compute.Expression -> substrait -> DF` then we don't need to worry about this.
- [ ] https://github.com/apache/arrow-datafusion/issues/7249 - Lance's planner is capable of handling timestamp literals with a specified precision (to choose between second/millisecond/microsecond/nanosecond resolution).  Datafusion's planner can't yet handle this.  So we need to add this capability to DF if we want to avoid a regression.
- [ ] we need to investigate / confirm DF's capability to handle UDFs and UDTs.  Example from `@eddyxu` : `we might want “Select * From … Where image_size(img) >= (256, 512)”`

title: Roundtrip schema metadata
body: We have a field for schema metadata in the manifest, but we don't deserialize it from the protobuf message in Lance.

title: feat: transaction files and commit conflict resolution
body:
This PR introduces a new file: `Transaction` files. These describe the incremental changes a commit is attempting to make or has made. They are described entirely by a protobuf message. These files are considered optional, and thus these changes are backwards compatible. No feature flags are needed.

The commit flow has been refactored based around the transaction files. Writers that find a conflicting writer has beaten them to a commit will now retry up to 5 times, using their transaction data to re-build the manifest. Importantly, before retrying writers will validate that their changes are compatible with the changes that have been committed concurrently.

title: feat: upgrade arrow to 43.0 in duckdb-lance
feat: upgrade to datafusion 28.0.0 and arrow 43.0
body:
Datafusion added a new `DisplayAs` trait (with method `fmt_as` that can be parameterized by a `verbose`/`default` style) which is inherited by `ExecutionPlan` and thus must be implemented on all our custom nodes.  Currently, I am just defaulting to existing `fmt` implementation regardless of the requested style (this seems to be the pattern used in most datafusion nodes as well).

Datafusion added a new parameter to the `like` function for `case_insensitive` which maps, in SQL, to `LIKE` vs. `ILIKE`.

title: Add method to quickly check for and load latest version
body: It would be nice to have a method to load the latest version of a dataset that is already loaded, and do so as cheaply as possible. Importantly, the cache should be kept, and the cost of checking for a newer version should be no more than a HEAD request.

Implement L2 normalization for f16/bf16/f64. No SIMD yet. 

Aarch64 neon instructions do not have f16/bf16 instructions.

title: Be able to round-trip null struct values
ci: fix the release commit script
body: Pushing a new tag isn't useful if it doesn't contain the changes we want.

title: feat(api!): make create_index mutate self
body: Closes #1114.

title: Add function to delete dataset versions
body:
Right now we keep all versions of a dataset, but to save disk space, we'd like to remove older versions.

The API might allow removing a specific version or all versions before one.

```python
dataset.delete_versions(1)
dataset.delete_versions(1, 3, 4)
dataset.delete_versions(before=7)
```

To perform this operation, we first need to crawl the metadata for files present in existing versions. This includes both data files, deletion files, and index files.

Then for each version to be deleted, determine which files aren't part of the existing file set. Delete those objects and the corresponding manifest file. Use [ObjectStore::delete_stream()](https://docs.rs/object_store/0.6.1/object_store/trait.ObjectStore.html#method.delete_stream) for maximum efficiency.

For operations like this, we'd like to provide the option for the user to distribute the operation. So there could be a single node implementation (configurable to use one or multiple threads) and a multi-node implementation, which returns a vector of tasks. See implementation of file compaction for inspiration: https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/1095

title: Merge deletion vector cache into file metadata cache
body:
We have a specific cache for deletion vectors, but we recently added a more generic cache that is longer lived, so we should merge it into that.

Deletion vector cache: https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/dacfda0cfaab62dc83871488ead90053f17d8c25/rust/src/io/deletion.rs#L337-L343


File metadata cache is part of the session: https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/dacfda0cfaab62dc83871488ead90053f17d8c25/rust/src/session.rs#L69

title: Support array_contains in filter
body:
We support `column IN (<literal values>)` but don't support `array_contains(list_column, <literal_value>)`, even though this is quite useful.

To support this, we'll need to add new logic to handle parsing SQL into DataFusion logical expression:

https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/dacfda0cfaab62dc83871488ead90053f17d8c25/rust/src/io/exec/planner.rs#L295

And then add logic to handle translating the logical expressions into physical ones here:

https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/dacfda0cfaab62dc83871488ead90053f17d8c25/rust/src/io/exec/planner.rs#L368

See changes here for blueprint: https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/983/files

title: Make Dataset.create_index take &mut self
body: We had a bug (#1112) that wasn't caught because after creating an index we were using the old dataset instance. It wasn't obvious that we should be using the returned updated dataset. Other APIs like `merge()` and `delete()` take `&mut self`, which avoids this issue. We should follow suite with `create_index()` to avoid these kinds of confusions, both for ourselves and our users.

title: fix: take and search now work properly with deletions
body:
Closes #1112

Fixes several bugs related to deletions in take and vector search. This includes:

* `Fragment.take()` previously would return fewer rows than requested if there are deleted rows. Now the method will map the indices to valid row ids (skipping deleted rows), and will always return exactly the number of rows requested. The docs are also updated to describe this desired behavior so we can avoid the confusion in the future.
* `Dataset.take_rows()` now works even if there are deletions. Previously it was built assuming that running `take()` (now `take_rows()`) on a fragment would return exactly the number of rows requested, which isn't guaranteed if there are deletions. `take_rows()` has been modified to return `_rowid` so we can reconstruct the requested order in `Dataset.take_rows()`.
* `VectorIndex` is cached and re-used between versions of a dataset. However, it contained `LruDeletionVectorStore`, which had a reference to a particular manifest. This caused queries to be wrong because they were using cached deletion vectors from a different version of the dataset. The `LruDeletionVectorStore` was removed and replaced with the `FileMetadataCache` in `Session`. More importantly, the session is now passed down for each query as `PreFilter`, so the indices can be safely cached and reused across multiple versions of the dataset.

title: Take doesn't work with deletions
body:
Right now, you can supply indices to the `take()` method, and it will return a record batch exactly equal in length to the input indices. To implement this, we map those indices to internal row ids. However, with deletions, these internal row ids might have holes in them, and so now we might return fewer rows than requested.

The current take implementation doesn't expect this, and will crash if there are deletions. However, we want to maintain the property that `take()` returns exactly the number of requested rows. So to solve this, we need to adjust the mapping of index to row id so that it skips the deleted row ids.

title: Runtime improvements
body:
This umbrella issue covers improvements to the runtime experience of Lance.
 
* [ ] Support cancelling long-running commands
* [ ] Support optional progress bars for long-running commands
* [ ] Separate CPU threadpool and IO threadpool
  * See https://thenewstack.io/using-rustlangs-async-tokio-runtime-for-cpu-bound-tasks/
* [ ] Allow disabling use of multi-threading in queries
* [x] #736

title: Fragment::create() needs to honor max_row_per_group
Add user guide page for vector search
body:
We have a [quickstart page](https://lancedb.github.io/lance/notebooks/quickstart.html#vectors), but we should have a page describing vector search in detail.

This should include basics of how vector search works, when indices need to be updated, how to tune query parameters, how to speed up training, and so on.

title: Update Lance quickstart prose
body:
https://lancedb.github.io/lance/notebooks/quickstart.html

It could use a little more detail and cross reference other parts of the documentation.

title: [Rust] Keep track of in-progress Write on the Fragment level
body:
To be able to identify unsuccessful write in a distributed environment, to allow later recover / garbage collection, we should allow the `Fragment::Write()` to track the progress of writing.

For example, we could set a `fragment.json.inprocess` when the write process starts, and delete it when the write finishes.
